description: Erection of 1no.x 2 storey, 3 bedroom detached dwelling, erection of two storey side extension to existing dwelling.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andxx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

Prior to any above ground works of the development hereby permitted, details of all visible facing materials shall have been submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture. The development shall be implemented in accordance with the approved details. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to the dwellinghouse(s) hereby permitted (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Before occupation of the dwelling hereby permitted, an biodiversity enhancement strategy shall have been submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority. Swift boxes shall be considered for inclusion. The strategy shall be implemented in accordance with the approved details and all features shall be retained in that manner thereafter.Reason: To safeguard and protect and enhance biodiversity and nature conservation value in accordance with Policy DM6 (Biodiversity) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the dwelling hereby permitted, a landscaping scheme including soft and hard landscaping shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to any above ground works to the dwelling hereby approved, a scheme of noise insulation/reduction shall be submitted to ensure that the noise level of 35 dBL Aeq,16 hour in living rooms and bedrooms during the daytime (0700 to 2300 hours) and 30 dBL Aeq,8 hour and 45 dBL Amax during the night time (measured with F time-weighting and between 2300 and 0700 hours) in bedrooms in accordance with BS8233:2014 shall not be exceeded. Where these levels cannot be met with windows open appropriate acoustic ventilation should be provided so that the room can be sufficiently ventilated. The acoustic performance of any passive vent, variable speed mechanical air supply unit or whole house ventilation must be sufficient to ensure that the noise level standards given above are not compromised.Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity for residents, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans, prior to the occupation of the dwelling hereby approved, details of the means of enclosure, along all site boundaries, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details and timetable and shall be retained permanently. Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity and to safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in the interests of the character of the area, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The flood resilience and resistance measures and SuDs measures shall be implemented in accordance with the Flood Risk Assessment dated 24 September 2020 and retained thereafter. Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding to and from the site in accordance with relevant policy requirements including but not limited to London Plan Policy 5.13, its associated Sustainable Design and Construction SPG, the Non-Statutory Technical Standards for Sustainable Drainage Systems and Kingston Council's Local Plan Policy DM4.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with BS5837: 2012 "Trees in relation to Design, Demolition and Construction". The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The refuse and recycling facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained thereafter. Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the approved plans, prior to the occupation of the dwelling hereby permitted, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of the existing andproposed levels across the site shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planningauthority. The development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development and to ensure satisfactoryliving conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site comprises a mid-terrace dwelling, located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill, Strategic Area of Special Character.5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History- 23/00088/CEU - Retention of roof terrace and bridge. Approved 15.03.2023- 22/01929/HOU - Conversion of garage into habitable space, erection of single storey front extension, installation of bifold door in rear and internal alteration. Refused on 12.08.2022.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development and non-designated heritage assets.- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The applicant previously submitted an application with the same development description which was refused for the following reason:Due to the proposed bi-fold doors facilitating the use of the unauthorised terrace shown in the plans/elevations, the proposed development would harm the residential amenities by reason of loss of privacy. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.The applicant has subsequently obtained a Certificate of Existing Use for the retention of the roof terrace and bridge, which was approved. Notwithstanding, the proposed bi-fold door would be situation at the ground floor rear which is considered to have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the host building. Officers note that the proposed front extension and garage conversion would be considered acceptable, as neighbouring properties on Kelvedon Road benefit from similar extensions and the extension would respect the design of the existing dwelling.Overall, officers consider the proposed development to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposals would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. HeritageParagraph 203 of the NPPF 2021 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: The proposal would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area, as such officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill, Strategic Area of Special Character.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The existing garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking by failing to comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the omission of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking.Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations has been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:  Officers note that the proposal would have a large footprint, however, it would have a modest height, maintains 300mm - 400mm from the neighbouring boundaries and given that it would be situated in a fairly substantial rear amenity area, officers consider that it would appear as a subordinate addition to the host property, and would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.While officers note that the proposal would have many characteristics of a separate unit, given that the proposal has been submitted as a householder application, and that the submitted drawings do not indicate that it would be used as separate accommodation, officers consider that it would not be used for any other purpose other than ancillary/incidental use to the main dwelling house. In any case, a planning condition would secure this in the event of an approval.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire Safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, it does not suffiecently address the requirements of Policy D12(A). Officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Condition 7 (Boundary Treatment) of planning permission 19/03124/FUL states:Prior to the occupation of the approved development, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected.  The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the  Core Strategy Adopted (2012).Officer response: The submitted information is considered to be sufficient. As such, details submitted for Condition 7 are hereby approved.Condition 8 (Landscaping Scheme) of planning permission 19/03124/FUL states:The development hereby approved shall not be occupied until a landscaping scheme has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority including planting of trees, shrubs, plants and areas to be grassed. The landscaping shall be carried out in the first planting season after commencement of the development unless agreed otherwise in writing by the Local Planning Authority, and shall be maintained for a period of 5 years. Such maintenance shall include the replacement of any shrubs and trees that die. Reason: To ensure the provision and maintenance of trees, other plants and grassed areas in the interests of visual amenity and in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).Officer response: The submitted information is considered to be sufficient, it is noted that the Council's Tree Officer raised no objections to the proposal. As such details submitted for Condition 8 are hereby approved.Condition 10 (Cycle Facilities) of planning permission 19/03124/FUL states:Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, details of the secure cycle facilities shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved cycle store details shall be made available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012) and Policy 6.9 of the London Plan (2016).Officer response: The submitted information is considered to be sufficient. As such, details submitted for Condition 10 are hereby approved.

If multiple conditions are submitted in a single application and one is found to be unacceptable, the LPA can refuse the entire application, therefore, rather than applying for multiple conditions in a single application, the applicant is encouraged to apply for a single condition at a time.

The site comprises a detached dwelling. The site is located within Cranes Park, a Local Area of Special Character.19 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development and non-designated heritage assets; and,- Sustainable Transportation- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed single-storey rear extension would have a partial flat roof height of approx. 2.7m and a partial pitch roof height of 3.8m with a total depth of approx. 3.8m which would be in line with Policy Guidance 33 of the Residential Design SPD. Overall, the rear extension would appear subordinate and proportionate to the host dwelling and the wider area.Whilst it is noted that the proposed dormer would not be set down from the ridge, the roof extension/dormer extension would be well suited to the existing dwelling. It would maintain a sloped roof on the two-storey rear/side extension towards the southern side of the dwelling and would not be visible in the streetscene. The proposed garage conversion would be visible from the streetscene, as it would not retain the existing garage door. However, the proposed front elevation would still be in keeping with the fenestration pattern of the existing site and would adequately maintain the appearance of the streetscene. It is considered the proposal would not cause a significant negative impact on the streetscene of Cranes Drive.Overall, the proposed development is considered acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 and 25 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy, subject to conditions.HeritageParagraph 203 of the NPPF 2021 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: As noted above, although the proposed development would not generally be in keeping with the Residential Design SPD, it would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area, but rather preserve it. As such officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Cranes Park, a Local Area of Special Character.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The existing garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking by failing to comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the omission of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking.Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a residential-detached dwelling.19 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History- 23/00802/NMA - Non Material Amendment to Planning Permission 22/00841/HOU (Erection of single-storey rear extension with 2no roof lanterns) to change the roof design. Refused 05 May 2023- 22/00841/HOU - Erection of single-storey rear extension with 2no roof lanterns. Approved 12 May 2022- 21/03733/HOU - Erection of single storey rear extension. This application was Refused on 18 Jan 2022.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The applicant previously submitted an application for a single-storey rear extension(part pitched part flat roof) which was approved (22/00841/HOU). The applicant then submitted a non-material amended  for a flat roof instead which was refused for the following reason:The proposals would result in a decrease in the overall height, however, the height of the extension would increase in proximity to the neighbouring boundary due to an increased eaves height. The proposed changes and potential impact on neighbouring amenity and character and appearance are therefore considered not to be non-material.The proposed development under this application consists of single storey rear extension with a flat roof height of approx. 3.1m and a depth of approx. 3.5m falling outside the guideline set out in Policy Guidance 33, of the Residential Design SPD.  However, the proposal would appear subordinate and propionate to the host dwelling and it would not be visible in the streetscene. Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Officers acknowledge that neighbouring property No.6 Clippesby Close is the closet in proximity to the proposed rear extension. Although the existing window closest to the extension may be slightly affected, it would not be unacceptable as the door also provides light to the kitchen space.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a flat which includes the first floor and loft, in a semi-detached building. 12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representation has been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed hip-to-gable/dormer roof extension would not comply with the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, as it would upset the symmetric appearance of the semi-detached building. However, in the context of other houses in the street or wider area, the construction of a hip-to-gable would not be unusual and the dormer would only be slightly visible in the streetscene.Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is not considered that the proposal would significantly increase overlooking over and above the existing opportunities for overlooking already available from the first floor rear windows. Overall, given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
